A Mn2O3 catalyst was investigated for soot oxidation in gasoline exhaust. Catalytic studies performed in model exhaust with Mn2O3/soot mixtures in tight contact showed efficient soot oxidation above 250 °C. This high performance was additionally confirmed on a gasoline engine test bench using a Mn2O3-coated particulate filter. The mechanism of the oxygen transport from the gas phase to soot was investigated by kinetic modeling of O2 adsorption and desorption as well as catalytic studies using 18O2. As a result, it was suggested that O2 dissociatively adsorbs on Mn2O3 followed by surface migration and transfer of oxygen to the soot at physical contact points between the two solids. The surface, sub-surface and bulk oxygen of the catalyst were also found to play a role. Enhanced participation of bulk oxygen appeared with declining O2 content due to partial reduction of Mn2O3 and formation of oxygen vacancies driving the oxygen mobility. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Gasoline exhaust Soot oxidation Mn2O3 catalyst Mechanism Isotopic labeling Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Combustion engines are widely used to supply of electricity and heat and represent the most prominent propulsion technology for transportation. Currently, combustion engines are predominately powered by fossil diesel and gasoline fuels, with biogenic and synthetic fuel components becoming increasingly important to reduce the output of CO2 [1,2]. In this context, fuel cell electrical vehicles (FCEVs) and battery electrical vehicles (BEVs) are also the subject of intense research and development in the transportation sector. Diesel and gasoline engines differ in their specific combustion concepts involving compression and spark ignition. For gasoline-powered passenger cars, engines with port fuel injection are mostly used, involving the pre-mixing of air and fuel in an external manifold. Gasoline direct injection (GDI) was also introduced in the 1990 s to increase the engine efficiency and reduce the emission of CO2. By 2017, approx. 60% of newly registered gasoline vehicles were equipped with GDI engines [3]. However, one crucial issue affecting GDI is the output of particulate matter (PM), which is more pronounced compared to port fuel injection [4]. PM formation is mainly induced by incomplete fuel volatilization, causing fuel-rich zones, the impingement of fuel to piston and cylinder surfaces and resulting pool fires [5–8]. Since soot particles are cancerogenic and contribute to the greenhouse effect, the PM output of GDI engines was limited in the European Union (EU) by 2009. Moreover, the tightened Euro 6 level introduced in 2017 regulated the particulate number [9]. Taking into account stricter emission limits in future, such as Euro 7 and post-Euro 7, gasoline particulate filters (GPFs) are becoming increasingly relevant for gasoline cars. GPFs operate in wall flow mode very similarly to diesel particulate filters (DPFs), which have been well-established in diesel engines since the Euro 4 tier in 2005. Wall flow filters include the mechanical separation of PM by alternately plugging channels, forcing the exhaust to flow through the porous walls. However, the accumulation of the soot can increase the back pressure of the filters, potentially leading to a reduction in fuel efficiency and/or an increase in the CO2 output, and even to engine damage. Hence, a reliable strategy for the regeneration of particulate filters is necessary. For diesel vehicles, two methods are widely applied. Passive regeneration involves the removal of the trapped soot by oxidation with O2 and NO2. NO2 is much more reactive than O2 and is produced by NO oxidation on diesel oxidation catalysts (DOCs) located upstream of the DPF [10–12]. Though passive regeneration is sufficient for heavy-duty vehicles, passenger cars additionally require active regeneration. This strategy involves the post-injection of fuel, which results in a temperature rise in the DPF to burnoff the deposited soot [13]. However, suitable amounts of NO2 and O2 are not available in gasoline exhaust as the stoichiometric combustion conditions limit the potential of both active and passive regeneration [14]. Therefore, soot oxidation catalyst coatings on the GPF are being considered. These catalysts oxidize the trapped soot by O2 when the exhaust temperature is sufficiently high. In the past, soot oxidation catalysts were extensively investigated for diesel engines, showing that notably Ce, Ce-Zr, Fe and Mn oxides are promising catalysts [15–27]. However, one serious disadvantage of these catalysts is their need for tight physical proximity to the soot particles; loose contact only results in relatively little enhancement of the soot oxidation. Due to this restriction, soot oxidation catalysts are currently not used as a standard tool to regenerate diesel particulate filters. Nevertheless, since the exhaust temperatures of stoichiometric gasoline engines are significantly higher than that of diesel engines (max. 700 °C vs. max. 550 °C [3,14,28]), it is worth investigating soot oxidation catalysts for GPF regeneration. By contrast, the low proportions of O2 in stoichiometric gasoline exhaust (approx. 0.1–1 vol%) are challenging, but their effect on catalytic soot oxidation has not been investigated so far. Recently, we have studied the kinetics of soot oxidation on a manganese oxide catalyst prepared by flame spray pyrolysis (FSP). This indicated that there is pronounced soot conversion into CO2 even at an O2 fraction of 1 vol%. It was likewise shown that an increasing O2 fraction strongly accelerates the oxidation rate, whereas the light-off temperature was hardly affected [29]. Against this background, the present article deals with the evaluation of the above-mentioned FSP-made manganese oxide catalyst in terms of the oxidation of soot in stoichiometric gasoline exhaust. The catalytic activity was investigated in a model gasoline exhaust by systematically varying the O2 content. Furthermore, the reaction mechanism was elucidated using isotopically labeled oxygen. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation and physico-chemical characterization of catalyst and soot The manganese oxide catalyst was produced by FSP as reported lately [29,30] followed by thermal treatment at 550 °C for 30 min in static air atmosphere to obtain pure Mn2O3 phase. For clarity, the most important physico-chemical properties of this sample are summarized in Table 1 [29]. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was used to analyze the phase composition of the sample before and after the catalytic tests. The diffractogram was recorded on a D8 Advance Bruker AXS diffractometer from 10° to 90° with a step width of 0.01° and a time of 3 s per step using Cu-Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) and a Goebel mirror. Phase composition was determined based upon Rietveld refinement. Commercial carbon black (Printex U, Evonik Degussa) was used as a model soot. Its physico-chemical properties were recently reported [29] and are summarized in Table 2 for clarity. Although the O content of Printex U (2 wt%) is rather low, the oxidation kinetics are quite similar to real GDI soot samples of low reactivity [14,31,32]. The existence of highly reactive GDI soot was also reported, revealing clearly higher oxidation rates compared to diesel soot and Printex U, while similar activation energies were obtained for the different soot samples [33]. 2.2 Studies of catalytic activity in model gasoline exhaust The catalytic studies were performed in a model gasoline exhaust using temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO). TPO involved increasing the temperature from 25° to 800°C at a rate of 3.3 K/min while supplying the model exhaust (500 ml/min, STP) composed of 0.1–1 vol% O2, 2 vol% H2O and N2 for balance. These O2 contents reflect rich (0.1 and 0.2 vol%), rather stoichiometric (0.3 and 0.5 vol%) and slightly lean exhaust conditions (0.8 and 1.0 vol%) covering the operation range of gasoline engines [34,35]. Additionally, a study was conducted in the absence of oxygen. O2 and N2 (Air Liquide) were dosed using gas flow controllers (Bronkhorst), while water was added by passing the O2/N2 mixture through a saturator at room temperature (approx. 20 °C). The TPO investigations were performed in a quartz glass tube reactor (i.d. 10 mm) with a fixed bed containing a mixture of 900 mg Mn2O3 (5.7 mmol) and 60 mg Printex U (approx. 4 mmol C) in tight contact. The blends of catalyst and soot were prepared by grinding on medium for 15 min employing a Pulverisette 0 ball mill (Fritsch). The ground mixtures were pelletized (4 MPa), granulated and sieved to a size fraction of 125–250 µm. Moreover, a loose contact blend of catalyst and soot was prepared by mixing both solids in a glass container. The temperature was detected by K-type thermocouples positioned directly in front of and behind the packed bed. The online analysis of CO and CO2 was carried out with a hot measuring FTIR spectrometer (MultiGas 2030, MKS Instruments) using a lambda probe (LSU 4.9, Bosch) for O2. For reference purposes, a non-catalytic TPO study was performed with 60 mg of soot granules diluted with 120 mg of quartz wool to avoid a rise in the temperature due to exothermic soot oxidation. The feed consisted of 1.0 vol% O2, 2.0 vol% H2O and N2 for balance. The CO oxidation activity of the catalyst was additionally investigated using the same amount of Mn2O3 as in the soot oxidation. Before the TPO tests, the sample was pretreated at 450 °C for 15 min in 10 vol% O2 (N2 balance) and cooled to 50 °C in N2. Subsequently, the gas mixture consisting of 0.1 vol% CO, 500 vppm O2 and 2 vol% H2O or 2 vol% CO, 1 vol% O2 and 2 vol% H2O (N2 balance) was dosed and TPO was started as in the case of soot oxidation. 2.3 Studies of catalytic activity on gasoline engine test bench For the tests in real gasoline exhaust, a cylindrical cordierite-based particulate filter (NGK Europe, D: 118.4 mm, L: 120 mm, cell density: 240 cpsi, wall thickness: 9.5 mil) was coated with the Mn2O3 catalyst resulting in a load of 20 g/l. Before the coating a dispersion of the powder catalyst in H2O (50 g/l) was prepared and stabilized by stirring for approx. 10 min using a magnetic stirrer. The coating was made by dipping the substrate into the stabilized dispersion followed by drying at 120 °C. This procedure was repeated several times. Finally, the filter was treated at 300 °C for 1 h in static air. The coated filter was integrated into a home-made metal housing and was fixed using a commercial mat (3 M Interam Mat mount 100). For reference purposes, a bare filter was used. The canned filters were adapted to fit a modern turbocharged direct-injection four-cylinder internal combustion (IC) engine operating with spark ignition (Audi, TFSI, 125 kW). The specifications of the engine are summarized in Table 3. The intake air is tempered to 21 °C ± 1 °C via an external conditioning unit, and the intake air mass is recorded by a Bosch HFM air mass meter. The fuel mass flow for direct injection is recorded via a Coriolis mass flow sensor (Siemens SITRANS MASS2100). The engine speed is set and kept constant by the connected electric motor with inverter in four-quadrant operation independent of the engine power. A torque measuring flange (HBM T40) records the transmitted force. The air ratio is determined by a lambda probe (Bosch LSU 4.9) in the exhaust tract. The pressure of the fired cylinder is indicated using a temperature-controlled piezoelectric pressure sensor (Kistler 4061B) and a miniature piezoresistive pressure sensor (Kistler 4005B). A filter test section (total length 746 mm) is used to analyze the particulate filters. It is installed in the exhaust line directly downstream of the 3-way catalytic converter. The exhaust gas temperature was measured by K-type thermocouples located directly upstream and downstream of the filter. The pressure was detected by piezoelectric pressure sensors (Kistler). Gas analyses were carried out in front of and behind the filter by means of built-in measuring probes using a Testo XL 350 system, which includes the electrochemical detection of CO, NO, NO2, O2, H2 and H2O and infrared absorption spectroscopic monitoring of CO2. Before the tests, the entire engine was conditioned at 60 °C, while the temperature of the fuel and intake air was kept at 21 °C. For the warm-up, soot deposition and soot oxidation, different operation points (OPs) were applied as described in Table 4. OP1 was used for the warm-up, while OP2 was chosen to study soot deposition onto the catalytic and bare filter employing rich engine operation (λ = 0.77) for 45 min. To check the resulting soot loading, the respective filter was dismantled and heated to approx. 150 °C using a hot air blower followed by weighing with a precision balance. A corresponding weighing procedure was conducted with the unloaded filters. Subsequently, the loaded filter was integrated into the bench again and soot oxidation was started by establishing OP3 or OP4 (each at λ = 1.10). This achieved exhaust temperatures at the filter outlet of 500 °C and 600 °C (tested for conditions without soot deposition and oxidation, respectively). 2.4 Isotopic studies with 18O2 TPO investigations of Mn2O3/soot mixtures were carried out with 18O2 to elucidate the mechanism of the oxygen transport under O2-poor conditions, which are typical for gasoline exhaust. The fraction of 18O2 (Campro Scientific) was varied from 0.1 to 1.0 vol% using tight contact mixtures (960 mg) of Mn2O3 and Printex U as described in the previous section. The total gas flow was 500 ml/min (STP) taking N2 for balance·H2O was not dosed, so the origin of the species containing 16O could be unambiguously ascribed to Mn2O3. The TPO was performed by ramping up the temperature at 3.3 K/min. Then, the sample was cooled to 100 °C in N2 flow and a temperature-programmed reduction using H2 (HTPR) was conducted. This was done by supplying a blend of 2 vol% H2 and 98 vol% N2 while heating at a rate of 20 K/min; the total flow was kept at 500 ml/min (STP). The HTPR was carried out to quantify the amount of 18O incorporated into the catalyst during the isotopic TPO. In the TPO and HTPR studies, the gas phase was continuously monitored by means of online quadrupole mass spectrometry (Cirrus 2, MKS Instruments). The products (16O2, 16O18O, 18O2, C16O2, C16O18O, H2 16O, H2 18O, H2) were specified according to their mass/charge ratio (m/z). The COx and H2O balances of the isotopic studies were verified by additional TPO investigations supplying 16O2 and using online FTIR spectroscopy (MultiGas 2030, MKS Instruments). The temperature was monitored as in the catalytic tests (Section 3.2). 2.5 Temperature-programmed desorption of O2 The interaction of O2 with the Mn2O3 catalyst was investigated by means of the temperature-programmed desorption of O2 (O2-TPD), employing a quartz glass tube reactor (i.d. 8 mm). The Mn2O3 powder sample was pelletized, granulated and sieved as done in the catalytic studies (Section 3.2). The obtained granules (500 and 900 mg) were introduced into the reactor as a packed bed, pretreated and saturated at 150 °C with a gas mixture of 20 vol% O2 and 80 vol% N2 (Air Liquide) at a flow rate of 500 ml/min (STP). After cooling to 50 °C in N2 (500 ml/min), the TPD was started by linearly increasing the temperature to 900 °C at a heating rate of 3.3, 10 and 15 K/min while adjusting a N2 flow of 200 ml/min (STP). The temperature and O2 were continuously monitored as in the isotopic studies (Section 3.3). 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Effect of O2 on the soot oxidation activity of the Mn2O3 catalyst in model gasoline exhaust The effect the Mn2O3 catalyst exerted on soot oxidation in the model gasoline exhaust was evaluated by means of TPO using tight contact mixtures of Mn2O3 and soot and O2 fractions between 0.1 and 1 vol%. To assess the catalytic activity, the temperature of maximum CO2 formation (TCO2,max) is taken, since it is a prominent feature of the TPO profiles. As expected, the efficiency of the catalyst is enhanced by the increasing content of O2 ( Fig. 1), which is reflected by a shift of TCO2,max to lower temperatures accompanied by inclining CO2 fractions. The TCO2,max values are demonstrated in Table 5, showing that the lowest TCO2,max appears of 321 °C (1 vol% O2), while the highest is found at 399 °C (0.1 vol% O2). Note that in all the TPO studies the soot is completely oxidized, as deduced from the total quantity of COx produced. Moreover, at O2 proportions of 0.5 vol% and below, the TPO profiles clearly broaden, and for the smallest O2 content (0.1 vol%) a second CO2 maximum is observed at 550 °C followed by a plateau up to approx. 720 °C. This high-temperature CO2 production is attributed to non-catalytic soot oxidation, since during TPO with bare soot forming, COx is formed in a very similar temperature range (400–730 °C, TCO2,max = 650 °C). CO represents the main product of the non-catalytic soot oxidation with an overall selectivity of 73%. The formation of CO is related to the decomposition of CC(O) surface groups originated from the oxidation of the soot (CC(O) → CO(g) + Cf); Cf is a reactive C atom, on which O2 can subsequently chemisorb [36]. By contrast, the CO formation is negligible in the presence of the Mn2O3 catalyst, as indicated by overall CO2 selectivities above 99% (Table 5) even for the lowest O2 content of 0.1 vol%. The high selectivity towards CO2 is already associated with marked CO oxidation activity of the Mn2O3 catalyst above 175 °C (Fig. S1), as proven by the reference tests. This is in line with the literature [16]. Moreover, it should be noted that in the TPO investigations, the temperature difference between the inlet and outlet of the catalyst/soot bed increases during the soot oxidation. The temperature rise strongly depends on the O2 fraction and is highest at the peak COx formation, corresponding to the maximum heat production during the exothermic oxidation of soot (‘C′(s) + O2(g) → CO2(g), ΔH0 = –396 kJ/mol) as well as CO (CO(g) + 0.5 O2(g) → CO2(g), ΔH0 = –283 kJ/mol). The maximum temperature rise (ΔTmax = Tout – Tin) is listed in Table 5 and ranges from 15 K (0.1 vol% O2) to 31 K (1 vol% O2). It has lately been shown that a local temperature rise in the catalyst/soot mixture can enhance the soot oxidation kinetics, resulting in the self-acceleration of the conversion [29]. However, compared to O2-rich conditions (≥ 5 vol% O2), which provide ΔTmax values in the range of 40 K [29], the temperature rise is moderate in the present TPO studies due to the relatively low O2 proportions (≤ 1 vol%). Fig. 1 also shows that the light-off temperature of the soot oxidation (approx. 225 °C) is not significantly affected by the proportion of O2. This is explained by a very similar initial reaction step and its activation barrier, which determines the initial conversion rates. It is generally accepted that the first step of the soot–O2 reaction is the thermal decomposition of existing surface oxygen compounds (SOCs) such as ether, carbonyl, lactone and carboxyl groups, resulting in the release of CO and CO2 and the formation of unsaturated carbon atoms, on which the further reaction with oxygen takes place [37,38]. The activation barrier of this initial activation process significantly depends on the type of SOC, ranging from 110 to 400 kJ/mol [39]. Furthermore, at O2 proportions of 0.5 vol% and below, the content of CO2 around its peak formation (approx. 340–480 °C) clearly exceeds the inlet fraction of O2, while O2 is completely consumed (Figs. S2–S7). This excessive output of CO2 suggests that oxygen of the catalyst is transferred to the soot and/or is involved in the follow-up oxidation of CO, which is a primary product of the soot conversion. As a result, the catalyst is partially reduced in this regime of the TPO. Table 5 demonstrates that the amount of transferred oxygen (Ocat), estimated from the amount of oxygen present in CO2 exceeding the inlet O2 proportion, grows as the O2 fraction declines: it ranges from 0.36 mmol (0.5 vol% O2) to 1.42 mmol (0.1 vol% O2). Note that the Ocat proportions correspond to at most 8% of the total quantity of oxygen existing in the catalyst. To further evaluate the origin of these oxygen species, the theoretical abundance of surface oxygen was estimated using the diameter of O2− (1.26 Å), the BET surface area (21 m2/g) and the mass of Mn2O3 taken during the TPO (900 mg) [29]. As a result, the surface oxygen amounts to 0.63 mmol, which is close to the determined Ocat quantities (0.36–1.42 mmol). Thus, the release of oxygen from the catalyst (Ocat) and the resulting partial reduction of the Mn2O3 catalyst is mainly associated with the transfer of surface and sub-surface oxygen, but some participation of bulk oxygen cannot be excluded. Indeed, the involvement of bulk oxygen is already thermodynamically feasible at about 400 °C for extremely low O2 fractions, i.e., when the gaseous O2 is consumed. This oxygen supply is related to the crystalline transformation of Mn2O3 into Mn3O4 (3 Mn2O3 → 2 Mn3O4 + 0.5 O2), which potentially results in a release of 1.9 mmol O. That is clearly above the quantity of Ocat. By contrast, in the presence of O2 this transformation of the manganese oxide is thermodynamically favored only above approx. 650 °C for 0.1 vol% O2 and 725 °C for 1 vol% O2 [40,41]. This presence of oxygen is indicated by the appreciable rise in the O2 fraction above 700 °C, i.e., well after the total conversion of the soot. Furthermore, the catalyst is promptly reoxidized during the TPO, when O2 is again available in the gas phase, i.e., after the peak production of CO2 and substantial soot conversion, respectively (Figs. S2–S7). XRD confirms the exclusive presence of Mn2O3 when the catalyst is quenched after the complete consumption of the soot (approx. 520 °C) in the case of TPO with 1 vol% O2 (Fig. S8). However, one exception is TPO with an O2 fraction of 0.1 vol%, during which the soot is only consumed totally at approx. 740 °C accompanied by the entire conversion of O2 in a broad temperature range from 295° to 710°C. The total abundance of O (n(Ocat)) present in CO2 and exceeding the O2 proportion amounts to 2.72 mmol. This excessive amount of Ocat includes the theoretical quantity of 1.90 mmol O related to the conversion of Mn2O3 into Mn3O4. Additionally, the XRD analysis carried out after the full soot conversion (Fig. S9) confirms the predominant appearance of Mn3O4 (> 99%) with only a minor amount of Mn2O3 (< 1%), as expected from the thermodynamics [42]. Moreover, the amount of Ocat (2.72 mmol) indicates the further removal of O from the catalyst in addition to the crystalline transformation of Mn2O3 into Mn3O4 and O2 (1.90 mmol O). This additional quantity (0.82 mmol) corresponds to an oxygen removal of 5% from the remaining Mn3O4 catalyst, tentatively ascribed to surface and sub-surface oxygen species. Thus, the oxygen balance and XRD both demonstrate that the very low O2 fraction of 0.1 vol% causes a drastic reduction in the bulk and surface of the manganese oxide associated with the strong participation of catalyst oxygen in the soot oxidation. This substantial involvement of oxygen from the catalyst is related to the lack of gaseous O2, which is completely converted in the wide temperature regime from 295° to 710°C. It should be mentioned that soot deposited on a real particulate filter is often loosely contacted to the catalytic coating, which is known to diminish the oxidation performance of the catalyst [16]. Therefore, the soot oxidation activity of the Mn2O3 sample was also tested in the loose contact mode. As expected from the literature [16], the loose contact Mn2O3/soot mixture reveals lower efficiency compared to the tight contact blend, which is reflected by the broadened CO2 profile (330–680 °C) and the activity shift to higher temperatures (Fig. S10). The decrease in performance under loose contatct conditions is associated with a reduced number of physical contact points between catalyst and soot limiting the supply of oxygen [16]. Furthermore, the temperature programmed reaction of the tight contact Mn2O3/soot mixture performed in the absence of O2 shows a clear shift of the CO2 production to higher temperatures ( Fig. 2) compared to the TPO studies, which were conducted with O2 (Fig. 1). Two CO2 maxima are observed at 440 °C and 580 °C, similar to the TPO with the lowest O2 content (0.1 vol% O2). Negligible CO formation appears above approx. 700 °C including an overall CO selectivity of 2%. Moreover, the CO2 formation in the region of 440 °C is estimated as 0.81 mmol (1.62 mmol O). This amount of oxygen is in line with the TPO studies showing increasing oxygen supply of the catalyst with decreasing O2 fractions (Table 5). Similar to the TPO studies, the oxygen transferred in the 440 °C region is mainly attributed to the crystalline transformation of Mn2O3 into Mn3O4 (3 Mn2O3 → 2 Mn3O4 + 0.5 O2) releasing 1.9 mmol O. Obviously, some surface and sub-surface oxygen species are also involved in the Mn2O3-soot reaction. Additionally, the CO2 production at around 580 °C reveals 1.96 mmol CO2 (3.92 mmol O) indicating strong oxygen loss of the remaining Mn3O4 corresponding to a reduction degree of 25%, which again refers to substantial release of bulk oxygen. 3.2 Soot oxidation performance of the Mn2O3 catalyst in exhaust gas of a full IC engine Table 6 confirms the beneficial effect of the Mn2O3 catalyst coated onto the particulate filter. When OP3 is adjusted corresponding to a temperature of about 500 °C, the soot conversion of the catalytic filter amounts to 75%, whereas a conversion of only 25% is achieved with the bare filter. Using the bare filter, a soot removal of 88% is only achieved at clearly higher temperatures (OP4), leading to a maximal temperature of 630 °C in front of the filter and 621 °C behind it ( Fig. 3). Fig. 4 shows the pressure loss over the filter, i.e., the difference in the backpressure in front of and behind the filter, while Fig. 3 demonstrates the temperature during the regeneration process. As expected, the pressure loss with both filters decreases continuously with time. OP4 has a higher exhaust gas mass flow than OP3 (127.6 kg/h compared to 87.1 kg/h) due to the higher exhaust gas temperature (Table 4). Therefore, the initial pressure drop across the uncoated filter is highest here. At OP3, huge differences between the two filters are evident due to the low temperature of about 500 °C in the filter (the maximum temperatures before the filter were 515 °C (bare) and 520 °C (coated)). The manganese oxide coating leads to an increased regeneration rate, which is evident from the greater decrease in the pressure drop compared to the uncoated filter. Over 35 min, the pressure loss falls by approx. 13 mbar (500 °C) and 36 mbar (600 °C) for the uncoated filter and approx. 18 mbar for the coated filter (500 °C). The pressure loss is significantly higher for the uncoated filter at the end of the regeneration process, which also corresponds to the results of the weighing measurements. The temperature curve during regeneration again shows a slight decrease (approx. 10 K) across the filter. The temperatures are almost constant at the end of the regeneration period. 3.3 Performance of the Mn2O3 catalyst compared with the literature Firstly, the activity of the Mn2O3 sample is compared with catalysts reported in the literature considering catalyst/soot blends in model gasoline exhaust. However, it should be noted that in contrast to the soot oxidation in the O2-rich diesel exhaust, only a limited number of studies exist so far that deal with stoichiometric gasoline exhaust conditions. Moreover, the comparison of catalysts from the literature is challenging, since reaction conditions such as the contact mode, catalyst/soot ratio, O2 proportion and O2 flow per soot mass often differ but strongly affect the soot oxidation. Despite these constraints, Fig. 5 roughly summarizes the activity of soot oxidation catalysts from the literature, investigated with gasoline-related O2 fractions from 0 to 1 vol%. Their performance is expressed in terms of TCO2,max and temperature at 50% soot conversion (T50); the latter is used due to the limited experimental data. The reported catalysts consist of CeO2-ZrO2-MnOx [43], CeO2-ZrO2 [44], ZrO2 and Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 [45], ceria-praeseodymia [46] [47], BaFe1−xCuxO3 and LaMnO3 perovskites [48] [49] and amorphous manganese oxide [50]. The list of test conditions in Table S1 indicates that all the catalysts described were evaluated in the absence of H2O. Thus, for fair assessment, the catalytic data of the present Mn2O3 sample are taken from the isotopic studies performed without a supply of H2O (Section 3.4). Fig. 5 shows that Ce0.8Zr0.2O2 [45] tested in supertight contact mode with an O2 fraction of 1 vol% performs best (TCO2,max = 300 °C), while Mn2O3 comes second with a TCO2,max of 321 °C and a T50 of 322 °C (tight contact, 1 vol% O2). Furthermore, the activity of Mn2O3 is enhanced by both H2O and an increasing O2 content, as shown under diesel-related conditions [29]. Finally, the performance of both Ce0.8Zr0.2O2, Mn2O3 and MnOx show that these catalysts basically have the potential to remove soot from particulate traps under operation conditions typical of gasoline engines. Note that the manganese oxide used in this study reveals high hydrothermal stability up to 750 °C and thermal stability up to 1050 °C, as recently shown for the as-prepared catalyst. Its functionality as a catalytic coating on a diesel particulate filter has also been proven for lean exhaust conditions [16]. In literature soot oxidation was also performed in the absence of O2 to evaluate reactive oxygen species present in respective catalysts. Depending on the temperature of COx evolution, surface oxygen (α-O; 310–500 °C), sub-surface oxygen (β-O; 450–650 °C), and bulk oxygen (γ-O; > 650 °C) is generally differentiated. Soot conversion was observed between 170 and 600 °C on MnOx catalysts indicating that the soot is mainly oxidized by surface-adsorbed and sub-surface oxygen [50]. Efficient soot oxidation in absece of O2 was also found for ceria-praeseodymia samples resulting in a release of 0.7–2 mmol O up to 500 °C [46]. This amount is in the same order of magnitude as reported for the present Mn2O3 catalyst (1.62 mmol) as shown in Section 3.1. 3.4 Interaction of O2 with the Mn2O3 catalyst The interaction of gaseous oxygen with the surface of the Mn2O3 sample is an important step for oxygen transport to the soot, and was investigated using O2-TPD. It should be noted that, in agreement with the bulk composition of the sample, the manganese cations on the surface exclusively exist in the form of Mn3+, as recently substantiated by XPS [29]. The O2-TPD profile obtained after saturation at 150 °C ( Fig. 6) exhibits comparatively minor low-temperature desorption peaking at 230 °C, and a strong high-temperature feature at about 800 °C. The previous O2 desorption ranging from 150 to approx. 350 °C with a maximum O2 fraction of approx. 85 vppm is ascribed to the associative desorption of surface oxygen; the released O2 amounts to 4 µmol, corresponding to an O surface concentration of 0.8 μmol/m² [50]. This value is in the range of related α-Fe2O3, exhibiting O surface concentrations of 0.2 and 0.9 μmol/m², respectively [24]. Moreover, the strong O2 desorption of the Mn2O3 sample observed between approx. 610 and 870 °C is associated with the crystalline transformation of Mn2O3 into Mn3O4. The release of O2 (0.54 mmol) agrees well with the theoretical amount of O2 (0.53 mmol) according to the Eq. 3 Mn2O3 → 2 Mn3O4 + 0.5 O2. As discussed in Section 3.1, this degradation of the Mn2O3 sample is in line with the thermodynamics [51]. Since the low-temperature O2 desorption lies in the temperature range in which the Mn2O3 sample is active for the soot oxidation, it can be assumed that oxygen species desorbing from the catalyst are involved in a spill-over to the soot. Thus, further insights into the kinetics of the O2 adsorption/desorption on the Mn2O3 catalyst are gained by numerical modeling. The model involves the dissociative adsorption and associative desorption of O2 (Eq. 1) on Mn3+ surface sites (✼) and is based on a mean field approximation assuming each adsorption site to be equal [22,52–55]. (1) O2(g) + 2 ✼ ⇌ 2 O ✼ The kinetics of the adsorption (r1) and desorption (r2) are described by Arrhenius-type rate expressions (Eqs. 2 and 3), where Ai is the respective pre-exponential factor, Ei the activation energy, R the molar gas constant, c the O2 concentration in the gas phase and θO the surface coverage by O. Additionally, it is supposed that the activation energy of the desorption decreases linearly with growing surface coverage due to the repulsive interactions of the O adsorbates [22,54,56]. This is expressed in Eq. 3 by implementing the activation energy at zero coverage (E2(ΘO=0)) and the constant factor α. (2) r 1 = A 1 ⋅ exp − E 1 R ⋅ T ⋅ c ⋅ 1 − θ O 2 (3) r 2 = A 2 ⋅ exp − E 2 θ O = 0 − α ⋅ θ O R ⋅ T ⋅ θ O 2 The balance of gaseous oxygen is based on a stationary CSTR reactor model (Eq. 4), which is a fair approximation of the experimental setup used [57]. The differential change in the surface coverage upon TPD is described by Eq. 5. In both equations, F is the flow rate, Sact is the active surface area derived from the BET surface area and the sample mass, β is the heating rate during TPD and Γ is the surface site concentration (8.48·10−7 mol/m²). The latter is estimated from the high-temperature desorption of NH3 upon a NH3-TPD investigation of the Mn2O3 sample. (4) 0 = F ⋅ c in − c out − S act ⋅ ( r 2 − r 1 ) (5) d θ O dT = r 1 − r 2 β ⋅ Γ The numerical model is integrated into MATLAB software using the ode15s function to solve the surface balances. To reduce the numerical degrees of freedom, the pre-exponential factor A1 was derived from the kinetic theory of gases (Eq. 6), where NA is Avogadro’s number, M the molar weight of an oxygen molecule and am the area which an adsorbed O2 molecule occupies (6.2·10−20 m²) derived from the kinetic diameter of 280 pm [58]. S0 (0.35) is the initial sticking coefficient on a Mn surface [59]. A1 results in an overall value of 1.58 m/s, which correspond to the mean value of A1 at the mean temperature of 225 °C. (6) A 1 = N A ⋅ R ⋅ T ⋅ a m ⋅ Γ ⋅ S 0 2 ⋅ π ⋅ M ⋅ R ⋅ T Furthermore, the adsorption is considered to be an unactivated process, i.e., E1 = 0 kJ/mol, since the energy barrier of the O2 adsorption is assumed to be low [22,54,56]. For numerical estimation of the remaining kinetic parameters (A2, E2, α), the MATLAB function lsqcurvefit was used with the trust-region-reflective algorithm. The accuracy of the fit was evaluated with the nlparci function providing the 95% confidence interval. For the fitting procedure, the O2-TPD profile shown in Fig. 6 was used. Only the low-temperature O2 desorption was considered. The high-temperature release of O2 was omitted, since it relates to the crystalline rearrangement of the sample and does not cover the temperature regime of the catalytic soot oxidation studies (Section 3.1). The fitted O2 trace and the resulting O surface coverage are shown in Fig. 7 and indicate that the model, with its kinetic parameters, reproduces the O2-TPD pattern very well and reasonably simulates the evolution of the surface coverage. The kinetic parameters of the model are listed in Table 7. They evidence an energy barrier of O2 desorption (E2(ΘO=0)) amounting to 95 kJ/mol. Note that this activation energy reflects the enthalpy of O2 adsorption, which is assumed to be unactivated. Indeed, a very similar O2 adsorption energy of 103 kJ/mol was reported for Mn sites on a MnO2 (001) surface [60]. This adsorption energy is related to the comparatively low strength of the bond between the surface oxygen and the Mn2O3, obviously enabling the surface diffusion of surface oxygen. By contrast, higher energy barriers are known for the O2 desorption from Pt (183 kJ/mol) [52], Cu/CeO2(110) (121 kJ/mol) [61], Co3O4 (114 kJ/mol) [62]. The kinetic model was also validated by predicting further TPD experiments. For this purpose, O2-TPD investigations were performed with another Mn2O3 mass (900 mg) and heating rates (3.3–15 K/min). The simulations satisfactorily predict the experimental O2-TPD traces ( Figs. 8–10), substantiating the relevance of the numeric model and the implemented kinetic parameters. The maximum deviation of the fractions simulated from the experimental O2 is below 20 vppm, while the difference in the temperature related to the peak O2 proportion is below 35 K. Furthermore, the kinetic model is used to compare the rates of O2 adsorption and desorption with the soot oxidation at the lowest and highest O2 fractions (0.1 and 1.0 vol%, respectively) and at 250 and 350 °C each. For a fair comparison, the soot oxidation kinetics were derived from the isotopic TPO investigations (Section 3.4), which were carried out without H2O. The O2 adsorption/desorption was simulated based on the kinetic model adopting the experimental conditions of the isotopic TPO but omitting the presence of the soot ( Figs. 11 and 13). In these simulations, the non-steady mass balances of the gas phase and catalyst surface (Eqs. 4 and 5) were used. This required β/dT to be replaced with dt in the surface balance. The O2 desorption rates (r2) and O coverages calculated for 250 and 350 °C (Figs. S11–S14) show that it takes less than 1 s to achieve a steady state at which the O2 adsorption (r1) and desorption rates (r2) are equal. The respective values depending on the temperature and the O2 content are listed in Table 8. Since the catalytic soot oxidation was investigated with a much slower heating ramp of 3.3 K/min (0.06 K/s), the stationary O2 adsorption/desorption rates are taken for the comparison with the soot oxidation kinetics. The determined soot oxidation rates are also demonstrated in Table 8. They show that for the two temperatures and O2 fractions, the O2 adsorption/desorption (0.58…6.8 mol/s) is several orders of magnitude faster than the CO2 formation (10−9…10−6 mol/s). The adsorption and desorption of O2 on the catalyst thus obviously does not drive the kinetics of the soot oxidation. However, since the desorption of oxygen is very fast and the binding strength of surface oxygen to the Mn2O3 is rather low, a spill-over of catalytic oxygen to adjacent soot particles cannot be excluded as an oxygen transport mechanism during the soot oxidation. A spill-over of this type has been reported, for instance, for CeO2 and Cr2O3 catalysts and includes the dissociative adsorption of O2 followed by the produced oxygen atoms being transferred to the soot without physical contact between the catalyst and soot [25,63]. The different oxygen transport mechanisms are investigated in detail in the next section. 3.5 Mechanistic role of the Mn2O3 catalyst in the soot oxidation 3.5.1 Catalytic oxygen transport from gas phase to soot Further insights into the oxygen transport from the Mn2O3 catalyst to the soot are gained by the isotopic TPO studies of the Mn2O3/soot blend using labeled O2 (18O2). These investigations were performed with the same gasoline-related O2 fractions as selected for the investigations in Section 3.1. In contrast, the isotopic studies were performed in the absence of H2O to accurately monitor the contribution of oxygen (16O) from the catalyst. To balance the mass of 16O and 18O, HTPR was conducted after each isotopic TPO test, while the respective amounts of oxygen were obtained by integrating the mass spectrometric traces that were recorded. To unravel the oxygen transport routes, TPO was used with 1 vol% 18O2, followed by HTPR. The effect of the O2 content on the oxygen transport is considered in the next section. The TPO study with 1.0 vol% 18O2 (Fig. 11) demonstrates the formation of C16O2, C16O18O and C18O2 including the complete conversion of the soot at 530 °C. TCO2,max appears at approx. 360 °C, which is a shift to a higher temperature of about 40 K compared to the TPO performed in the additional presence of 2 vol% H2O (Fig. 1). The enhancement of the catalytic and non-catalytic soot oxidation due to H2O is known from the literature and is explained by the formation of reactive oxygen through the dissociation of H2O on the soot surface [64]. Moreover, during isotopic TPO, C18O2 and C16O18O are the major products, with an overall selectivity of 53% and 38%. By contrast, only a small amount of C16O2 is formed, with an overall selectivity of 9%. However, in the initial phase of the soot oxidation (120–300 °C, Fig. S15), C16O2 develops first, followed by C16O18O, and almost no C18O2 appears. This predominant formation of C16O2 is related to the thermal decomposition of 16O-containing SOCs in the soot, such as phenol, carbonyl, lactone, quinone and carboxyl groups [37,38]. As a result, C16O and C16O2 are produced. The former is potentially oxidized on the catalyst to form C16O2. The formation of C16O18O during the initial TPO phase is interpreted as being due to the oxidation of C16O by 18O present on the catalyst surface (18Os), i.e., C16O(g) + 18Os → C16O18O(g). The existence of 18Os is ascribed to the exchange of 18O2 and 16O from the catalyst surface (16Os), which already occurs above 200 °C, as substantiated by the appearance of 16O18O (18O2(g) + 16Os ⇌ 16O18O(g) + 18Os) and small amounts of the follow-up product 16O2 (16O18O(g) + 16Os ⇌ 16O2(g) + 18Os) It should be noted that this oxygen exchange on the catalyst surface involves the dissociation of 18O2 as considered in the kinetic modeling of the O2 adsorption and desorption (Section 3.3). By contrast, the gas phase exchange of 18O2 with the oxygen of CO2 does not take place at these temperatures [16,23]. Note that the formation of H2 16O and H2 18O, which is ascribed to both the dehydroxylation of the catalyst and the oxidation of the hydrogen-containing functions of the soot, e.g., carboxylic acid and phenolic groups [37], is negligible (Table 2). Moreover, no indication of C16O and C18O was found due to the high CO oxidation activity of the catalyst (Fig. S1). The overall quantities of C16Ox 18Oy that develop during the TPO show an incorporation of 2.66 mmol 16O in C16O2 and C16O18O ( Table 9). This 16O proportion represents approx. 16% of the total oxygen in the original Mn2O3 sample, while the quantity of surface oxygen estimated in Section 3.1 amounts to 0.63 mmol only. By contrast, the quantity of 16O initially present in the soot (approx. 0.1 mmol) is negligible (Table 2). Thus, these numbers evidence that the 16O atoms present in carbon dioxide mainly originate from bulk oxygen, which is either transferred to the soot particles or involved in the CO oxidation. Surface and sub-surface oxygen obviously also participate. It should briefly be mentioned that after the soot is almost completely converted at approx. 400 °C, the proportions of 16O18O and 16O2 increase with the temperature and reach a maximum at about 600 °C (Fig. 11). This effect is again ascribed to the exchange of 16O by 18O on the catalyst surface, which inclines with the temperature due to the increasing mobility of the inner oxygen [16,65]. The strong involvement of bulk 16O in the oxygen exchange is reflected by the large amount of 16O18O (7.45 mmol) representing approx. 44% of the total oxygen content of the Mn2O3 sample. Indeed, the incorporation of 18O in the catalyst was confirmed by HTPR, performed directly after the isotopic TPO ( Fig. 12). As a result, 0.94 mmol H2 16O and 3.83 mmol H2 18O were formed in total, corresponding to an overall quantity of 4.77 mmol of oxygen. This proportion is below the theoretical amount of H2O (5.70 mmol) if the thermodynamically favored MnO is assumed to be the final product of HTPR [66]. An XRD analysis of the sample performed after HTPR confirms the complete phase transformation to MnO during the exposure to H2 in line with the thermodynamics [60] (Fig. S16). The difference to the theoretical abundance of oxygen released during HTPR (4.77 vs. 5.70 mmol) might be due to some thermodynamic transformation of Mn2O3 into Mn3O4 (3 Mn2O3 → 2 Mn3O4 + 0.5 O2) in the final phase of TPO, when high temperatures up to 800 °C are reached; this conversion was already discussed in detail in Section 3.1. To quantify the 16O substitution by 18O, the total amount of 16O is balanced via isotopic TPO and subsequent HTPR. This balance includes an 16O input of 17.10 mmol (Mn2O3), while the output equals 13.62 mmol due to the production of CO2 and H2O, and the exchange of O2 (Table 9). The residual proportion of 16O (3.48 mmol) obviously remains in the catalyst after HTPR in the form of MnO (Fig. S16). Since the initial amount of Mn2O3 suggests a final quantity of 11.40 mmol MnO, the resulting difference of 7.92 mmol is ascribed to the incorporation of 18O. Indeed, the 18O balance (Table 9) involves an input of 99.04 mmol and an output of 91.87 mmol, pointing to the accumulation of 7.17 mmol in the form of Mn18O. This number is very close to the corresponding amount from the 16O balance (7.92 mmol) and substantiates the relevance of the 16O and 18O balances. Moreover, the proportion of 18O (7.17 mmol Mn18O + 3.83 mmol H2 18O) incorporated into the catalyst after the TPO corresponds to an oxygen exchange level of 64% in the initial Mn2O3 sample. However, it should be stated that the majority of the 18O incorporation is related to 16Os interacting with gaseous 18O2, which mostly occurs after the soot has been fully consumed. As already stated above, during the soot oxidation, 2.66 mmol 16O is transferred to CO2, which corresponds to 16% of the initial Mn2O3 oxygen. This is predominately made up of bulk oxygen, but some is surface oxygen (at most approx. 0.63 mmol) and sub-surface oxygen. The importance that the oxygen in the Mn2O3 catalyst assumes in the soot oxidation agrees well with the conclusions drawn from the oxygen balance (Ocat) in Section 3.1. The formation of the C16O2, C16O18O and C18O2 species in the isotopic TPO is associated with the transfer of 16O and 18O from the catalyst to the soot. It is assumed that the oxygen atoms form reactive C16O, C18O, C16O2, C16O18O and C18O2 surface compounds on the soot. These SOCs decompose, yielding the corresponding CO and CO2 as primary products, similarly to the oxidation of the bare soot (Fig. 1) [37,38]. The C16O and C18O molecules that are released subsequently react with surface 16O and 18O from the catalyst, producing carbon dioxide according to the overall equation C16,18O(g) + 16,18Os → C16Ox 18Oy(g). The efficient CO oxidation activity of the catalyst was already discussed in Section 3.1 (Fig. S1). It has recently also been shown that soot oxidation on the manganese oxide is affected by physical contact between the catalyst and the soot. Tight contact between the two solids produces a good performance, whereas loose contact results in a relatively low level of activity, though the catalyst still has a beneficial effect compared to bare soot [16]. This finding indicates that intimate contact between Mn2O3 and soot drives the oxygen transfer from the catalyst to the soot. It has also been suggested that this physical contact is important for related catalysts such as CeO2 [67], Fe2O3 [36], Cr2O3 and Co3O4 [63]. We strongly believe that contact between the Mn2O3 and soot particles enables the constant transport of oxygen from the catalyst to the soot, ensuring the continuous formation of C16O2, C16O18O and C18O2. This “contact mechanism” would require sufficient contact between the two solids up to high soot conversion levels above 95%, as inferred from the permanent production of CO2. Contact of this kind during soot oxidation has been proven for Fe2O3 [36] and CeO2 catalysts [67] using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). For CeO2, in-situ TEM studies have even shown that during the conversion, soot particles attached to the CeO2 catalyst move towards the contact surface with the catalyst, ensuring that oxygen is constantly transferred from the catalyst. Based on the modeling of the O2 adsorption and desorption (Section 3.2), as well as the isotopic TPO investigation, it is suggested that the oxygen transport involves the dissociative adsorption of gaseous O2 on the Mn2O3 surface, followed by surface diffusion to the contact points of the catalyst and soot. At these physical contact points, the surface oxygen is then transferred to the soot. The participation of the sub-surface and bulk of the catalyst is explained by oxygen migration. This is driven by oxygen vacancies occurring as oxygen is released to the soot and consumed by reaction with CO. The mobility of the bulk oxygen also increases with the temperature and is driven by the reduction of the catalyst, which provides an increasing number of oxygen vacancies. It is important to note that the oxygen migration is strongly affected by the consumption of oxygen by the soot, and by CO oxidation, which mainly occurs at the surface of the catalyst. As a result, vacancies are produced, driving the migration of inner oxygen. By contrast, without this chemical activation, the bulk diffusion of oxygen occurs only at much higher temperatures [51,65,68,69]. It has furthermore been shown that the release of surface oxygen from the (001) surface of Mn2O3, which produces a surface vacancy, requires an energy barrier of approx. 105 kJ/mol [51]. Interestingly, this value is close to the activation barrier (69 kJ/mol) recently estimated for the soot oxidation on Mn2O3 at an O2 fraction of 1 vol% and above. Thus, it can be speculated that the oxygen transfer from the catalyst might be the determining step of the soot oxidation on Mn2O3. By contrast, the initial decomposition of SOCs on the soot, producing reactive carbon atoms, is not considered the rate-limiting step, since this process requires far higher activation barriers, from approx. 110–400 kJ/mol [39]. However, in addition to the “contact mechanism”, which is the predominating oxygen transport route, the isotopic investigation and the kinetic modeling of the O2 adsorption and desorption do not exclude the possibility that some role is played by oxygen spilling over from the catalyst surface to the soot. This is mainly associated with the relatively low binding strength of the O adsorbates on the Mn2O3 catalyst (< 95 kJ/mol) and the clear appearance of 18O, originating from the gas phase 18O2, in the C16O18O and C18O2 species. The transfer of oxygen from the catalyst to the soot, and the subsequent oxidation of the primary product CO on the catalyst, lead to the formation of oxygen vacancies that are not completely refilled by gas phase O2. These surface vacancies drive the migration of oxygen from the sub-surface and the bulk, resulting in the reduction of the catalyst. Further details of the O transport are discussed in Section 3.4. 3.5.2 Effect of O2 fraction on the catalytic oxygen transport mechanism In the previous section, the isotopic TPO profile obtained for the highest 18O2 proportion (1.0 vol%) was shown and discussed in detail. In particular, it was demonstrated that C18O2 is the predominant product with 1.0 vol% 18O2. The TPO investigations with the remaining 18O2 contents of 0.1 0.2, 0.3, 0.6 and 0.7 vol% and the respective HTPR analyses taken after each TPO are depicted in Figs. S17–S26, while Tables S2–S6 reveal the corresponding oxygen balances. The total C16Ox 18Oy quantities formed in all the isotopic studies are summarized in Fig. 13, substantiating a continuously decreasing evolution of C16Ox (C16O2 and C16O18O) when the 18O2 proportion inclines. That is, the overall C16Ox quantity declines from 8.93 mmol (0.1 vol% 18O2) to approx. 4.4 mmol (0.7 and 1.0 vol% 18O2). In contrast, the amount of C18Ox (C18O2 and C16O18O) increases when the 18O2 content grows from 1.9 mmol (0.1 vol% 18O2) to approx. 12 mmol (1.0 vol% 18O2). Furthermore, it should be noted that the TPO profiles are clearly shifted to higher temperatures when the 18O2 content decreases ( Fig. 14). In particular, the temperature of the maximum CO2 yield moves from approx. 360 °C (1 vol% 18O2) to 387 °C (0.6 vol% 18O2) and 360 °C (0.1 vol% 18O2). It can also be stated that with 1.0 vol. 18O2 the soot is already completely converted at about 510 °C, whereas with 0.1 vol% 18O2 it is not entirely oxidized even at 700 °C. Very similar results were obtained in the tests performed in the presence of H2O (Fig. 1). For 18O2 proportions of 0.7 vol% and below, the CO2 formation exceeds the 18O2 inlet fraction, evidencing a reduction of the catalyst, as also found in the TPO studies with H2O (Fig. 1). This quantity of catalyst oxygen (Ocat) transferred to carbon dioxide is listed in Table S7 and is estimated from the amount of oxygen present in the isotopic CO2 molecules exceeding the respective proportion of inlet 18O2. As discussed in Section 3.1, the 2.55 mol of Ocat transferred in the presence of 0.1 vol% 18O2 comprises surface, sub-surface and bulk oxygen. The fraction of bulk oxygen drastically decreases as the 18O2 content increases (Table S7). In this context, the quantity of C16Ox, which grows along with the decreasing 18O2 content in the gas phase (Fig. 13), is due to the enhanced diffusion of bulk oxygen to the surface of the catalyst. The oxygen is then transferred to the soot at the contact points of catalyst and soot, as already discussed in Section 3.5.1. The acceleration of the bulk oxygen diffusion at a low O2 content is related to the increasing reduction in the surface and sub-surface of the catalyst, respectively provoking oxygen vacancies and oxygen concentration gradients inside the catalyst. The enhanced oxygen migration is also due to the higher temperatures required for soot oxidation at the low O2 fractions. However, for the higher 18O2 contents of 0.7 and 1.0 vol%, the involvement of catalyst oxygen (Ocat) is minor, i.e., 0.43 and 0.31 mmol (Table S4), showing that there is no significant diffusion of bulk oxygen. This effect occurs because more gaseous oxygen is adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, suppressing the driving force behind bulk diffusion. 4 Conclusions This article reports on a Mn2O3 catalyst for the oxidation of soot using model gasoline exhaust. The catalyst was recently proven to be a highly efficient means of oxidizing soot under diesel-like conditions. In the present study, tight contact blends of Mn2O3 and soot were taken using Printex U as a model soot. The model gasoline exhaust consisted of 2 vol% H2O and an amount of O2 that was systematically varied between 0.1 and 1 vol% to cover the O2 contents found in practice. As a result, the Mn2O3 sample exhibited substantial soot oxidation in the model gasoline exhaust, although it clearly contains lower O2 fractions (≤ 1 vol%) compared to diesel exhaust (≥ 3 vol%). The soot oxidation started at about 250 °C almost independently of the O2 content. This was related to the thermal decomposition of surface oxygen compounds, which was taken to be the initial reaction step in the soot oxidation. However, when the conversion proceeded, the expected rise in the soot oxidation was observed when the amount of O2 increased. This was self-accelerated by the temperature rise due to the exothermic reaction. The peak CO2 formation at the highest O2 content of 1.0 vol% appeared at about 320 °C, accompanied by a temperature increase of 30 K. By contrast, at the lowest O2 fraction of 0.1 vol%, the soot oxidation appeared over a broad temperature range up to 730 °C. This was associated with the limited availability of gaseous oxygen. Comparison with the literature shows that the Mn2O3 sample is one of the most effective catalysts of soot oxidation in gasoline-like exhaust. The efficiency of the catalyst was additionally validated on a 4-cylinder IC gasoline engine using a particulate filter coated with Mn2O3. The investigations showed that the catalytic coating reduced the regeneration temperature from 600 °C to 500 °C while maintaining the same high regeneration rate. However, the coating reduces the flow cross-section within the filter. This leads to a slightly greater pressure loss compared to the uncoated filter, requiring the thickness of the catalytic layer to be optimized. We have recently also reported on the catalyst’s hydrothermal stability (750 °C), thermal stability (1050 °C) and resistance to SO2 [16], substantiating its practical relevance. All in all, the results from the laboratory and the gasoline engine exhaust are very promising for the future development of highly efficient particulate filters. The mechanism behind the oxygen transport from the gas phase to the soot was investigated using isotopically labeled 18O2 and kinetic modeling of the O2 adsorption and desorption on the Mn2O3. The isotopic studies were systematically carried out with O2 fractions between 0.1 and 1.0 vol%, and showed that the Mn2O3 sample requires physical contact with the soot particles. This “contact mechanism” includes oxygen transport from the gas phase over the catalyst surface to the physical contact points, where the oxygen is finally transferred to the soot. In addition to the surface migration of the oxygen, sub-surface and bulk oxygen species are also involved in the oxygen transfer, driven by the partial reduction of the catalyst during the oxidation of the soot and CO formed as the primary product of the soot oxidation. The partial reduction of the catalyst and the production of oxygen vacancies increase as the O2 content decreases. As a consequence, inner oxygen increasingly participates in the oxygen transfer with a lack of oxygen in the gas phase. coredata.dc:description: A Mn2O3 catalyst was investigated for soot oxidation in gasoline exhaust. Catalytic studies performed in model exhaust with Mn2O3/soot mixtures in tight contact showed efficient soot oxidation above 250 °C. This high performance was additionally confirmed on a gasoline engine test bench using a Mn2O3-coated particulate filter. The mechanism of the oxygen transport from the gas phase to soot was investigated by kinetic modeling of O2 adsorption and desorption as well as catalytic studies using 18O2. As a result, it was suggested that O2 dissociatively adsorbs on Mn2O3 followed by surface migration and transfer of oxygen to the soot at physical contact points between the two solids. The surface, sub-surface and bulk oxygen of the catalyst were also found to play a role. Enhanced participation of bulk oxygen appeared with declining O2 content due to partial reduction of Mn2O3 and formation of oxygen vacancies driving the oxygen mobility.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidation of soot in gasoline exhaust on Mn2O3 catalyst
